description:
An intensive introductory lecture course covering the cell, molecular biology, biochemistry, and the genetics of animals, bacteria, and viruses. This course is comparable to Biology 101, but places greater emphasis on molecular mechanisms and experimental approaches. Particular attention is given to the ways in which modern cell biological and molecular genetic methods contribute to our understanding of evolutionary processes, the mechanistic basis of human disease, and recent biotechnological innovations. BIOL 121 and 123 must be taken concurrently. 

Biology Majors and Pre-Medical students should take either BIOL 101 or 121. BIOL 121 is the companion course to BIOL 124 and may be taken before or after BIOL 124.
name: INTRO BIO-MOLEC BIO LIFE

values.comments:
Formally known as “The Molecular Biology of Life,” the class introduces concepts including the cell, molecular biology, biochemistry, and genetics. The course is similar to BIOL 101, but emphasizes analysis of molecular mechanisms and experimental approaches. Attention will be directed to ways in which modern cell biology and molecular genetics methods contribute to understanding evolutionary processes, the mechanistic basis of human disease, and biotechnological innovations.

Students seemed to learn a lot and felt that the material covered was “adequate and useful.” Students appreciated that both lecture and exams emphasized “understanding concepts and biological processes" instead of “memorization.” A few students felt that course moved too slowly and addressed too few topics; additionally, some felt that there was coverage of extraneous topics such as the history of biology. Because the class has four professors, students should be prepared to deal with different and sometimes contrasting teaching styles.

The few comments that addressed Professor Goulian’s teaching abilities were generally fair. Students felt that he was engaging and communicated subject matter quite clearly. One student described him and a few other professors who taught the course as “gifted.” 

Most students taking this class were pre-medical freshmen and biology majors. Exams seem to be fair and test in-depth knowledge of the material. Students should expect a heavy workload due to the fair amount of memorization/understanding demanded by the course. The course is mostly recommended for majors and pre-medical students.
